intro: Haplopappus polyphyllus, commonly known as the many-leaved pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has a low, sprawling growth habit. Its leaves are usually narrow and linear, and the flowers are small, yellowish, and clustered in dense inflorescences. Haplopappus polyphyllus is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
